awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Determining climate related changes in water mass structure, paleoventilation, and paleocirculation in the Southeast Indian and Southern Oceans
awd_abstract_narration:
The modern oceans hold about fifty times more CO2 than the atmosphere, but scientists think this may have been even greater during glacial periods causing a significant reduction in the amount found in the atmosphere. Reduced atmospheric CO2 concentration during ice ages likely contributed to colder global temperatures. Much of the atmospheric-oceanic CO2 exchange takes place in the Southern Ocean and is associated with processes of oceanic and atmospheric circulation. By studying the water mass structure and chemical characteristics, scientists hope to define key controls over the exchange of CO2, namely where water masses rise and sink from the surface and the pathways they travel in the deeper ocean. This study will establish age models and allow detailed correlations between a unique set of sediment cores previously collected from the Indian Ocean.  These cores span a range of depths and locations that will support associated efforts of an international team of researchers to study and track important water masses in the area using a variety of chemical tracers found in the sediments deposited as the Earth transitioned out of the last glacial ice age into the modern climate. This work provides undergraduate student research opportunities and supports an early career post-doctoral scientist.

The circulation and ventilation of water masses at intermediate depths (~500-1400 m) in the Southern Indian Ocean are central to atmosphere-ocean CO2 partitioning. During glaciations, changes in both thermohaline circulation and wind-driven Southern Ocean ventilation are believed to have played an important role in sequestering atmospheric CO2.  A detailed understanding of the interaction between the physical mechanisms of thermohaline overturning circulation and wind-driven ventilation requires precise definition of changes in water mass boundaries and properties across the deglaciation.  The use of vertical and horizontal transects of sediment core material has been fundamental in identifying past variations in the structure of the ocean. Published transects of paleo-proxies in the glacial South Atlantic differ substantially from the Southwest Pacific, leading to the idea that processes in the Southeast Indian Ocean had a significant influence on glacial CO2 exchange. Consequently, this proposed work will provide foundational stratigraphy in a selected suite of six cores obtained on the CROCCA-2S cruise in 2018 (Coring to Reconstruct Ocean Circulation and Carbon-dioxide Across 2 Seas). These 6 cores have been selected to create depth and latitudinal transects underlying both subantarctic and subtropical waters in the Southeast Indian Ocean from a region west and south of Australia. Provisional multi-sensor core logger and CaCO3 data suggest coherent glacial-interglacial stratigraphies between these core sites. Efforts will concentrate on expanding this initial stratigraphy, principally via planktonic and benthic δ18O analyses.  Associated efforts will constrain surface frontal locations that shift in response to changes in atmospheric circulation, as well as deep water mass boundaries and properties that vary with ocean circulation patterns.  The ultimate scientific objective is to determine the temporal evolution of the horizontal and vertical distribution of proxies (e.g.13C, 18O, Nd isotopes) that will reconstruct the water source and ventilation history of this critical region of the Southern Ocean.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fifty times more CO2 resides in the ocean than the atmosphere. Exchange of CO2 with the atmosphere and the storage of CO2 in the ocean is an important control on atmospheric concentrations. During recent ice ages, atmospheric CO2 concentrations were naturally 30% lower than pre industrial levels. Extensive evidence indicates this reduction was caused by greater storage of CO2 in the ocean. Today, wind-driven air-sea exchange in the Southern Ocean is one of the primary mechanisms for CO2 exchange between these two reservoirs.  During the last glacial interval, reduced exchange in the Southern Ocean driven by changes in ocean circulation and the resulting changes in ocean chemistry is believed to have played an important role in sequestering more CO2 in the ocean; however, there is ongoing debate about the specific state of glacial oceanic circulation in the Southern Ocean. Previous studies have largely concentrated in the South Atlantic and Southwestern Pacific. There are clearly changes in the chemistry and circulation of water masses between these two regions, but work here focused on the critical region of the Southern Indian Ocean where very few sediment cores were previously available.  

Paleoceanographic reconstructions use paleo-environmental proxies that preserve a record of the parameter in question. The original objective of this work was to determine sub-surface water mass provenance and the storage and release of sequestered CO2 at the northern rim of the Southern Ocean. Funding was granted with the specific aim of producing detailed and reliable stratigraphy on a subset of cores selected from those that were obtained during a previously funded and successful coring voyage in 2018. An important component of utilizing new unstudied cores is stratigraphy: converting depth-down core to an estimate of time. Work here initially employed calcium carbonate percentages for an affordable and rapid assessment of sedimentation rate and stratigraphy.  Subsequently, stable isotopic markers, primarily the 18O of planktic foraminifera were used to refine estimates of stratigraphic age downcore.  This was supplemented in limited cases with radiocarbon dating. These efforts determined that the sedimentation rates in six of the cores selected were suitable for millennial scale analyses (see figure of sedimentation rates).  This revealed that a least four of these cores were suitable for sub-millennial resolution work. Whereas two cores (with lower sedimentation rates) appear to be suitable for glacial-timescale resolution paleoceanographic study. Determining that four cores had high enough resolution for sub-millennial resolution guided the choice to sample these cores for higher resolution analyses.  This intensified sampling allowed for the conversion of depth to age in these cores (see figure of 18O analyses).  These analyses on planktic foraminifera and the determination of solid stratigraphy in these cores sets the stage for further work, as was intended by the funding that was granted.  Next steps with the most recently secured funding will be to add to the planktic foraminiferal stable isotope analyses in hand (that have been used for stratigraphy), further, different, analyses that will fulfill the original scientific aims of the project. Analyses planned are: 1) neodymium isotopes on planktic foraminifera, which can be used to distinguish Atlantic- and Pacific- sourced waters. 2) benthic foraminiferal isotopes to address questions related to changes in deep ocean circulation and CO2 sequestration.

This work supported one post-doc and undergraduate student employment. Combined with work that was initiated with support for the original coring cruise this supported the publication of 1 paper and 12 abstracts presented at international meetings. Two more papers have been submitted.

 


Last Modified: 08/21/2023
Modified by: Elisabeth L Sikes
